description: Dive into "Discover Chuo: Unforgettable Free Gems" ‚Äî a handpicked list of places with quick notes, links, and essentials for fast trip planning and discovery.
title: Discover Chuo: Unforgettable Free Gems

places.generalDescription: The Sony Showroom, located in the impressive 11-story Sony Building, spans floors one to four and offers a hands-on experience with the latest Sony products. Visitors can explore cutting-edge gadgets that are not yet available for purchase and test out the newest PlayStation software on a large high-definition screen. The showroom was previously situated in the Sony Building near Sukiyabashi crossing in Ginza but has since relocated. It's known for its friendly staff and interactive experiences like virtual ball catching games.

sources.snippet: Taking up floors one to four of the impressive 11-storey Sony Building, the Sony Showroom gives you the chance to get your hands on the latest Sony products. On a visit to the showroom, you can fiddle with high-tech gizmos to your heart‚Äôs content, many of which aren‚Äôt even on general sale yet. You can even try out the latest PlayStation software on a giant, high-quality monitor.
sources.shortName: 15 Of The Best Free Things To Do In Tokyo

places.name: Sony Showroom/Sony Store Ginza

reviews.text: When I got a chance to travel to Japan, I instantly knew I had to visit some Sony store hahah. Such a nice place full of awesome tech, for a nerd and Sony fanboy like me a complete heaven. Employees are really friendly and helpful. This visit definitely made my day, and I'm sure I'll never forget it! Without no doubt best experience in Japan for me. üòÅüòÜ

Was nice to see some new and classic cars, however the place was a bit lacking, it was just 4 cars total and didn't really give much more information, much more of a marketing thing than an experience.
The coffee with the car on it was cool, and a good view and place to charge my phone was appreciated.
Nice place in central Ginza for a quick stop and sit down  but not a must see destination.

Located above the Nissan Crossing on the main Ginza shopping street, you'll find the Sony
Showroom and Store. Inside, Sony's latest products are on display, and visitors can interact with many of them. While most of the showroom is standard, the "aibo" robot dog is a definite highlight. I wouldn't recommend making a special visit just for the store, but it's worth a look if you're a Sony enthusiast. On the floor above there was a very nice exhibition of photos from Mongolia. And of course, the view of the building from outside is beautiful !

places.address: Ginza Place, 4-6F, 5 Chome-8-1 Ginza, Chuo City, Tokyo 104-0061, Japan

places.generalDescription: Kanda Shrine, also known as Kanda Myojin, is a revered Shinto shrine located in Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo. It has a rich history dating back over 1,000 years and is considered the collective guardian deity for 108 neighborhood associations in areas such as Nihonbashi, Akihabara, and Marunouchi.

sources.snippet: Kanda Myojin Shrine dates back to 730, when it was first built in Otemachi, which was then a fishing village known as Shibasaki. During the Edo period (1603‚Äì1867), the shrine was relocated to make room for the expansion of Edo Castle and was eventually rebuilt on its current site in 1616.
sources.shortName: The Best Free Things to Do in Akihabara

places.name: Kanda Myoujin Shrine

reviews.text: Went to Kanda Myoujin Shrine, and it was such a pleasant experience. Despite expecting it to be crowded, it wasn't as busy as I thought it would be. There was a festival happening at the time, adding a vibrant touch to the experience. I also tried some delicious street food nearby, which was a fun bonus! The combination of the beautiful shrine, the festive atmosphere, and tasty snacks made for a wonderful day out. Highly recommend checking it out if you're in the area!

Lovely shrine with a large main building with many smaller buildings around it. A visitor centre is built to the side and a museum can be found at the back of the shrine grounds. It seems like wedding ceremonies can also be arranged here.

However, this place feels very commercialised. I'm not sure how I should feel about a place of worship being commercialised to this extent...

This shrine is open 24 hours a day, so you can come to worship at any time. It also appears as a setting in anime, making it a must-visit spot for travelers who love Japanese animation and history üòäüòäüòä

places.address: 2 Chome-16-2 Sotokanda, Chiyoda City, Tokyo 101-0021, Japan

places.generalDescription: Ginza Sony Park is a must-visit attraction in Tokyo, offering a unique opportunity to experience cutting-edge technology and products before they are released. The park features various exhibits and attractions suitable for all ages, including workshops and a beautiful garden on the top floor.

sources.snippet: Opened in 2018 on the site of the former Sony Building, Ginza Sony Park takes you on an underground park experience. This vertical park begins on ground level and stretches 3 floors underground with each floor offering something different. The first floor is adorned with a variety of exotic plants which are for sale.
sources.shortName: 35 Best Things to Do in Ginza | Japan Travel by NAVITIME

places.name: Ginza Sony Park

reviews.text:
After finally reopening in early 2025, they have a brand new exhibit to go with their return here with various Sony artists being the theme of a series of interactive multimedia shows/experiences.

Currently it's Yoasobi, Hitsujibungaku ÁæäÊñáÂ≠¶, and someone else. Entry is free, but you need to make a reservation online ahead of time for a specific time slot. Very much worth the effort, especially the Hitsujibugaku show in my opinion.

The building itself is very open and well thought-out too; a great use of space, angles, and light that feels welcoming yet with its own character in every corner.

A welcome departure from the shopping-focused vibes in most of Ginza.

Really cool and interesting new building by Sony. The Sony restaurant in the basement is awesome. The food was delicious and they let you keep the menu as a souvenir. Aside from that the attractions are very cool. Though you need to book ahead of time as demand is high and they are changed after some time. When I went there was a very cool experience with haptics and water and I got to see Sony's new EV car on the roof of the building. I definitely recommend checking this place out in Tokyo.
reviews.author_name: It's time for a multipolar world

reviews.text:
Was able to attend an early opening preview of the new building with some art being exhibited. It's free and you can register on the website.

While it's under construction you cannot access every floor easily. Sometimes you can only take the stairs for one floor then you're forced to take the elevator. The worst thing is there is only one tiny tiny elevator. The best way to avoid waiting forever and being disappointed by a full elevator is to take the elevator from b2f which is actually located in ginza station. Do not enter via the street level.

places.address: Âú∞‰∏ã3Èöé, 5 Chome-3-1 Ginza, Chuo City, Tokyo 104-0061, Japan
